note: Highly convincing in terms of safety. No potential issues were found during human inspection.

The vulnerability mentioned in the public auditing report (https://veridise.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/VAR-circom-bigint.pdf) has already been fixed in this benchmark. Since the bit lengths of both `mod` and `div` are verified using `Num2Bits`, passing them to `BigLessThan` (and consequently to `LessThan`) is safe.

The vulnerability mentioned in the public auditing report (https://veridise.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/VAR-circom-bigint.pdf) has already been fixed in this benchmark. Since the bit lengths of both `mod` and `div` are verified using `Num2Bits`, passing them to `BigLessThan` (and consequently to `LessThan`) is safe.

Although this circuit, called `Decoder`, is non-deterministic with respect to the signal `success`, it enforces the constraint `dec.success === 1`, ensuring the correctness of the entire circuit.

Highly convincing in terms of safety, with no potential issues found during human inspection. Although ZKAP (USENIX'24) claims that IN is vulnerable to overflow attacks due to the lack of a bit-length check for GreaterThan(252), this claim is unfounded. The first argument of GreaterThan(252) is the sum of IsEqual's output, whose maximum value is the template parameter valueArraySize, while the second argument is 0. Therefore, this operation is safe.

Although ZKAP (usenix'24) flags this circuit vulnerable, not using the variable does not mean that the circuit is under-/over-constrained. The issue (https://github.com/0xPARC/circom-ecdsa/issues/29) has been not addressed by the developer, also suggesting that this circuit is likely to be safe
This circuit is not over-constrained with the default setting of Circom compile.

Although ZKAP (USENIX '24) flags this circuit as vulnerable due to the unused intermediate signal `values`, it is neither under-constrained nor over-constrained by our definition, as other parts of the circuit still depend on `values`.
